text: another arrest this time in Nuneaton in
Warwickshire as armed police from
Greater Manchester and forces nationwide
close in on what they say is a network
surrounding the Manchester bomber it's
not clear how critical or peripheral to
the investigation
many of these latest arrests are but one
thing police want above all else is to
find whoever supplied or built the bomb
that Salman our baby detonated with such
devastating effect but the publication
in the new york times of highly
sensitive crime-scene pictures and
information from the manchester
investigation has angered british police
chiefs and politicians at the highest
levels of white oak they described the
leaking of what should be confidentially
shared information from american
intelligence sources as a breach of
trust it undermines the investigation
and the BBC now understands that Greater
Manchester Police has stopped passing on
and sharing intelligence with American
agencies such is the fury within the
force an extraordinary move reflecting
how damaging many feel the leaks are it
worries me greatly and in fact I know my
concerns about it too the US ambassador
it's not acceptable to me that you know
here there was a live investigation
taking place and we cannot have
information being put in the public
domain that's not in the direct control
of the British police and security
services a clearer picture is now
emerging of who's Salman Abady was and
his descent into radical Islam in Libya
where his family originally came from
the Bombers younger brother and his
father are reported to have been
arrested the names and stories of more
of those who were killed on Monday night
are slowly being released 17 year old
Chloe Rutherford and her boyfriend Liam
Curie who was 19 was said to be
inseparable relatives said they live to
go to new places and explore different
cities it all still feels rather raw
Manchester as a city and its people have
been knocked sideways by what happened
this week amid the visibly heightened
security things certainly don't look or
feel normal
and despite the progress made by police
in the last two days there's still a lot
we don't know what a Davis BBC News
Manchester
